On Wednesday, June 17, as their spring service project, the middle school student leadership team known as the QMS Student Ambassadors held a "thank you parade" to honor staff at Glens Falls Hospital.

A caravan of nearly 40 cars made up of ambassadors and their family members, and QMS staff, including Mr. Gannon and Mrs. Troelstra, were part of the parade.

There were honking horns and cheers of gratitude, along with balloons and handmade signs displayed from car windows.

At the conclusion of the parade, the hospital staff was presented with lunch on behalf of the ambassadors.

Thank you to all who participated and a huge thank you to Mrs. Seelye, Mrs. VanVranken and our students!

#TBT to Friday's Senior Give Back Day:

Our seniors and faculty chaperones woke up before 9 a.m. to work in the sweltering heat last Friday. Some cleaned up roads, raked, weeded, dug in the dirt, helped to set up poolside/gazebo furniture and mulched for Gurney Lane Rec Park. Others made/donated masks, joined our elementary virtual classes to read to them, and sent thank you cards out to faculty and staff.

Even in a global pandemic our seniors found a way to give back to our community, while complying with health regulations.

Thank you to everyone that helped to pull this off! We are so thankful for staff and students that just keep giving. 💙💛

It's Food Service Friday and today we're highlighting the district's Farm to School Program.

On Jan. 23, Chef Steve Sutliff of Aramark; Annie Mills, Farm to School Program Coordinator for Cornell Cooperative Extension of Warren County; and nutrition intern Lisa Schmitt conducted a fruit smoothie tasting at QMS. The smoothies were in celebration of dairy, “the Harvest of the Month” for January, and the students unanimously selected that the winning smoothie was a combination of vanilla yogurt, apples, kale, strawberries, blueberries, mango, bananas and pears!

Under the Farm to School grant awarded to QUSD, breakfast and lunch menus include New York State sourced foods wherever possible. Ingredients for the smoothies included yogurt from Byrne Dairy, apples from Yonder Farms and kale from Torrey Farms. The rest of the produce is sourced through Antonucci Foods. 🐮🍎🥬

post_text: QES second grade students performed for kindergarten and first graders during the unveiling of a new character education superhero, Mindful Maestro last week! The character education program at Queensbury Elementary School aligns with the school motto, which says, “Work hard, do your best, achieve your dreams at QES.” The program focuses on four major character traits throughout the school year: Caring, Respect, Cooperation, Responsibility and the latest addition, Mindfulness. Mondays are now designated as 'Mindful Mondays,' when students will practice a skill that promotes being mindful, including affirmations, deep breathing and using calming strategies.

post_text: Students at QMS worked together to create a mural in the cafeteria. The mural was inspired by Kelsey Montague, an artist who creates wing murals around the country, asking the question "what lifts you up?" The Character Education committee is using the mural to ask the question "How do you rise above intolerance, bullying and “drama?” Art teacher Amy VanVranken said her favorite part of the process was being able to read each feather as she hung them. "It was very inspiring to read the words of our students."
